paper_metadata.title: Women for Women International economic and social empowerment programme impact on intimate partner violence and depression in Afghanistan

program_information.program_name: Women for Women International (WfWI) economic and social empowerment programme
program_information.region: Six urban and peri-urban communities in Kabul and Nangarhar
program_information.target_population: Conflict-affected women living in extreme poverty
program_information.program_name_citation: We assessed whether the Women for Women International (WfWI) economic and social empowerment programme could reduce women's experiences of intimate partner violence (IPV) and depression in Afghanistan
program_information.country_citation: We conducted a two-arm individually randomised controlled trial in six urban and peri-urban communities
program_information.target_population_citation: Communities were selected by WfWI for being conflict affected and showing signs of economic vulnerability (eg, little or no education, living in extreme poverty)

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: Women reported reduced food insecurity (β -0.48 (-0.85 to -0.12)), higher earnings (β 3.79 (0.96 to 6.61)) and savings (β 11.79 (9.95 to 13.64)). Women reported less gender-inequitable attitudes (β -0.89 (-1.15 to -0.62)), more household decision-making (β 0.35 (-0.04 to 0.74)) and increased mobility
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: We conducted a two-arm individually randomised controlled trial in six urban and peri-urban communities
